title: Bonmarche plunges into administration putting 2,900 jobs at risk
text:
Thousands of jobs were put in jeopardy last night as Bonmarche went into administration.

The over-50s fashion retailer, the latest victim of the crisis on the High Street, will continue trading while the brand looks for a buyer.

Chief executive Helen Connolly said: 'Over the last 18 months, trading in our stores and market conditions on the High Street have significantly worsened. This has overwhelmed the business and its financial position.'

Collapse: Over-50s fashion retailer Bonmarche has become the latest victim of the crisis on the High Street

She said the company would work with administrators to protect jobs and 'secure its future'.

The future of the firm's 2,900 staff and 318 stores is in doubt.

In the year to March 2018, the company made a £7.9million pre-tax profit on £186m of revenue.

Since then, sales have been deteriorating as staffing and business rate costs rose, leading to three profit warnings in six months.

In March it warned that losses could reach up to £6million this year.

It was bought out of administration by private equity firm Sun European Partners in 2012, and floated in 2013.

It is majority owned by retail tycoon Philip Day, who also owns Edinburgh Woollen Mill.

A further 2,000 jobs were put at risk by the collapse of Kairos, a Cheshire-based double-glazing firm.

Owner Brian Kennedy, 59, has a net worth of £375million and is best-known for bank-rolling the search for Madeleine McCann.
